SB 202 not only shrinks access to the ballot box, it gives the state General Assembly control over local elections—allowing lawmakers to pick their voters.
 
That’s democracy in reverse. 
https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/22368044/georgia-sb202-voter-suppression-democracy-big-lie

If Georgia expanded Medicaid today, we could help save the lives of hundreds of thousands of Georgians by providing affordable health care coverage, while also helping jumpstart our post-pandemic economic recovery & stabilize our rural health systems.

What are we waiting for?

The COVID-19 vaccine is one of our best defenses against this virus, and it will help Georgia—and our nation—fully reopen safely.
 
All Georgians ages 16 and older are eligible to get vaccinated. Make your appointment today:
https://myvaccinegeorgia.com

#VAWA included two of my amendments – one calls for safe housing for domestic and sexual violence victims, and one allows certain grants in the bill to be used to create databases detailing where SANE nurses are located. https://ross.house.gov/media/press-releases/ross-amendments-pass-house-reauthorization-violence-against-women-act

Since my time in the North Carolina House, I have championed the rights of victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. In Congress, I’m thrilled the US House voted to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act.
If you are a victim and are seeking help, you can call the National Sexual Assault Hotline at 1-800-656-4673.
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month – a time to reaffirm our commitment to survivors. I stand with you and will work in Congress to strengthen protections for those affected by sexual assault.

If you haven’t received your economic impact payment from the #AmericanRescuePlan, you can check the status of your payment using the “Get My Payment” tool here: https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/get-my-payment.

As direct payments from the #AmericanRescuePlan have already begun helping Illinoisans pay their bills, care for their families & support local businesses, it’s crucial that our seniors get the money that’s rightfully theirs. I’m glad this latest round of payments is on the way.

Most payments will be automatically deposited into banks accounts or loaded onto the Direct Express Cards where they receive Social Security benefits. Those waiting on paper checks or debit cards through the mail should expect to receive their payments over the next several days.

Today’s round of payments applies specifically to those who receive Social Security retirement survivor or disability (SSDI), Supplemental Security Income (SSI) & Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) benefits & who didn’t file a 2019/2020 tax return or didn’t use the Non-Filers tool.

🚨ATTN Illinoisans: Social Security recipients and others who have not yet received their Economic Impact Payments from the #AmericanRescuePlan should expect to see electronic payments hit their bank accounts or be loaded onto their Direct Express Cards starting today.

RT @RepCasten The pandemic caused a childcare crisis—forcing caregivers to choose between taking care of their kids and paying the bills & nearly a million mothers to exit the workforce.

The #AmericanRescuePlan made an unprecedented expansion to the Child Tax Credit.

Here’s how it works.🧵1/

At a moment when 1 in 8 children are going hungry and millions of families are struggling, it’s crucial that we all work together to ensure every parent has the resources to access the Child Tax Credit. Here are free tax filing resources for Illinoisans: https://www2.illinois.gov/rev/research/news/Pages/Free-Income-Tax-Preparation-for-Elderly-and-Low-Income-Families.aspx

The Child Tax Credit will lift half our nation’s children out of poverty and benefit over 90% of American families, but when I visited @TeenParentNP recently, I learned how many young mothers haven’t heard about the benefit or how to access it. 5/ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZN9JpXEAIxE7A.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZN9JsXAAsCl-G.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZN9KNWEAMdC_7.jpg

For folks wondering if they’ll be eligible for the Child Tax Credit for a baby born later this year, the answer is YES & the #AmericanRescuePlan includes a provision allowing anyone who gives birth in 2021 to receive the 3rd $1,400 check for that child after filing for 2022. 4/

Today I had the opportunity to meet with Cosley Zoo in Wheaton to discuss the impact they’ve had on our community during the pandemic. Community centers, like zoos, play an essential role in our community’s education on how to care for our planet and ecosystems. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZI2-hW8AUtxKY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZI2-gWYAcsogF.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZI2-fW8AEFfsY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZI2-kWQAAKv7n.jpg

The Child Tax Credit applies to your 2021 tax year, but the IRS will advance part of the credit in form of checks delivered or direct deposited as early as July, continuing through December. The remaining amount will be credited against your taxes when you file next year. 3/

If you earn <$75,000 or your household earns <$150,000 you’ll receive $3,600 for each child under age 6 & $3,000 tax for each child age 7-17.

If your income exceeds that threshold, the credit will be reduced by $50 for every additional $1,000 of income. 2/https://grow.acorns.com/child-tax-credit-calculator/

Mayor Turner said “these bills are Jim Crow 2.0."
 
Jim Crow voting restrictions included poll taxes, literacy tests, and grandfather clauses. It is absurd to make these comparisons since absolutely no provision would stop a person from voting.
Does any of that sound like racist voter suppression? No, of course not. The majority of these reforms simply unwind the “emergency measures” implemented during the pandemic.
6) Strengthens Ballot Security: Requires that voting machines are able to produce a paper audit trail and requires live streaming of counting for large counties.
5 contd) And population-based machine distribution is necessary b/c Democrats were packing their favored precincts with extra machines.
5 contd) This prevents you from getting someone else’s ballot, which often happens when the state universally mails out ballots based on addresses from imperfect registration rolls.

5) Secure and Fair Voting Locations: SB7 prohibits universal drive-thru voting, prohibits election officials from distributing mail in applications to people who didn’t request one, and ensures polling places and machines are distributed fairly based on number of eligible voters.

4) Uniform Voting Times: SB7 creates uniformity in early voting times to reduce confusion while ensuring at least 12 hours a day and polling places can be open until 9PM.

This fixes the different voting times in different counties that confused voters.

3) Increases penalties against ballot harvesting, the practice of gathering and submitting completed absentee or mail-in voter ballots by third-party individuals, volunteers or workers, rather than submission by voters themselves directly to ballot collection sites.

2) Stops Voter Assistance Fraud: HB6 protects individuals who require assistance (such as seniors or those with vision limitations) by *requiring information from the assister*. 

Why? Because these voters are more likely to be victimized by partisan activists.

Here’s what these bills actually do.

1) Accountability at Polls: Puts safeguards in place so poll watchers aren’t denied access, improving transparency and confidence in results. 

(Dem officials put obstacles in the way of poll watchers in the 2020 election. HB6 fixes that.)

The #EssentialCaregiversAct fights for our seniors and those with developmental disabilities living in long-term care facilities. It works to prevents LTC residents from being cut off from their caregivers during public health emergencies. 

READ: https://tenney.house.gov/media/press-releases/tenney-introduces-national-essential-caregivers-act-protect-seniors-and-other http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyZUKpoXIAMe9U6.jpg

We need to look at the existing financial resources – billions spread across the federal gov. – and figure out how do we recalibrate to better priorities? (4/4)

Right now, what we are throwing a nickel at every $10 problem across the country, which results in nothing being fixed. (3/4)
https://www.rollcall.com/2021/03/31/whats-in-bidens-infrastructure-investment-corporate-tax-plan/

We’ve heard infrastructure will encompass A to Z – whether that is broadband, climate, energy, roads and bridges, water, environmental and so on. 

We need a clear goal of, “What is it exactly we are trying to achieve?” (2/4)

Just because you add the word infrastructure behind another word, that doesn’t make it infrastructure.

We need to spend more time deciding the federal government’s role in transportation and infrastructure. (1/4) https://twitter.com/politico/status/1379777262132813827 QT @politico What *is* infrastructure?

That’s a question that will dominate politics for the spring and summer. https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2021/04/07/the-question-thats-about-to-dominate-politics-492386?cid=su_tw_pb

But we need to find a cooperative framework instead of a $2.3 trillion package, on top of the recent $1.9 COVID package, with only a fraction actually going to our transportation and infrastructure priorities.

We need a bill that would deliver a new bridge, reduce our traffic, make communities safer, advance ports or waterways and address head on our true needs. 

We have to dedicate our taxpayer dollars to the best areas possible. https://twitter.com/talk1073/status/1379808007547146243 QT @talk1073 Congressman @RepGarretGraves was on the show for his weekly D.C. Current segment to talk border control and infrastructure money.

It’s common sense that individuals should have to show ID to pick up opioid prescriptions, which are highly addictive and a contributor to the opioid epidemic. We need to do more to combat the opioid crisis, and H.R. 2355 will help do just that, saving lives in the process.

This legislation, inspired by a meeting I had with the Normal Police Department a few years ago, would empower law enforcement to monitor ‘pharmacy shopping’ and track bad actors who abuse opioid prescriptions.

Overdose deaths have accelerated during the pandemic, which has made it even more critical that law enforcement & health officials have more tools to fight drug abuse and opioid abuse. That’s why I re-introduced the Opioid Prescription Verification Act. https://rodneydavis.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=404052
